terms.definition: A technical document that provides step-by-step instructions and information to help users understand, operate, and maintain a product or software application.
Specialized writing that explains complex technical information, processes, or products in a clear and structured format for specific audiences.
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to view previous edits and maintain multiple versions.
Read The F***ing Manual - a common acronym used in tech communities to suggest that users should consult the documentation before asking for help.
An organized listing of a document's sections, chapters, and page numbers that serves as a navigation tool for readers.
A systematic approach to identifying, diagnosing, and resolving problems or issues with a product, system, or process.
The visual elements and interactive components through which users interact with software applications or digital products.
A sequence of connected steps or processes that define how tasks are completed from start to finish in a systematic manner.
Users who test pre-release versions of software or products to identify bugs, usability issues, and provide feedback before public launch.
A writing style where the subject of the sentence performs the action, making instructions clearer and more direct than passive voice.
Web markup language that automatically adapts and displays properly across different screen sizes and devices.
Portable Document Format - a file format that preserves document formatting and layout across different devices and operating systems.
The practice of designing documents and digital content to be usable by people with disabilities, including visual, hearing, and cognitive impairments.
Empty areas in a document layout without text or graphics, used strategically to improve readability and visual organization.
Specialized terminology or technical language specific to a particular field or industry that may be difficult for general audiences to understand.
